All of the political problems we face are ultimately the result of an old system trying to deal with new problems for which it is inadequate. If we want to fix the problems we face we need to start by looking at our legal system and its structure within its historical context and secondly realize the ways in which society has changed and thirdly determine whether or not those systems are adequate to the new social reality or if they need to be changed. Alimony is a perfect example. Alimony made sense 50 years ago when women primarily kept the home. The work was divided and hence the income despite being solely or primarily earned by the man should be divided as well. The social fabric has changed though and women have careers now and men share the duties at home. Before women had no sufficient work experience or income that they could rely on but now they do. Alimony was a proper solution to past problems but now is inadequate to current social realities. This is an area among many others that needs to be updated to deal with that new reality.

Wow, some interesting comments on this thread. Makes me glad I'm already married to a decent guy. Anyway, I actually agree with a lot of what these two said. But, I do think a lot of people are not understanding what is going on with feminism right now. So, for a long time, physical strength was what was needed to survive and men held most of the power because of that. Women gave birth and did the home stuff, and men went out and killed things and did all the 'man stuff'. Then we evolved and physical strength became less and less important to surviving and being successful, and yet we had evolved into these roles for thousands and thousands of years. Now, we live in societies where it's not physical strength, but ideas, etc that is valued and the balance of power started to shift. The problem is that when pendulums swing from one side, they don't just settle in the middle. The momentum swings it almost back as far to the other side before it loses its momentum and goes back to the center. What we are seeing right now is that the pendulum has swung too far one way and people are reacting. But, that was always what was going to happen. Knowing that will help us minimize the damage before things settle in the middle, which will be a slow process over time.

If you are in a rotten system, like a university where the leadership has more interest in protecting itself than the welfare of it's students or staff, you will probably find it very difficult to report a lecturer who's put a hand inbetween your legs whilst suggesting that you should discuss your grades over dinner. Try saying a clear 'no' to a guy that is deliberately blocking the exit in front of you (as happened to one colleague in my work a while ago when she was in an almost empty building). This is one of the dumbest conversations I've ever heard. Joe Rogan, you really need to do more homework on the subject because you're clearly misinformed. Alimony in no way means that men have to pay for women who don't deserve it. It means that the Higher earning spouse pays x amount of dollars per month to make their incomes reasonably equal—generally for one third as long as the marriage lasted. Meaning if you were married for 15 years you may have to pay alimony for 5, IF you happen to make significantly more than your ex spouse. I work at a family law firm and I can confirm that either party—husband or wife—can be ordered to pay alimony.

Also, there's no fucking way your friend has to pay alimony for the rest of his life unless he's a total idiot and signed a reeeeeaaaaallly shitty settlement agreement. Or there's something that you left out of the story, like he got to keep the million dollar house and the cars and their retirement and savings in exchange for an indefinite alimony arrangement.

Those are the situations that match the original situations those laws were intended for, in other words when one spouse has sacrificed their career for the purpose of taking on the housework and raising kids in full and allowing the other spouse to fully focus on their career. And this is exactly the same regardless of the sexes of the spouses. People who have spent potentially 20+ years of their prime career life out of work are most often not able to just hop back into work life and earn a pay to support themselves, whether it's a woman or a man. commentThread.commentText: Feminists are giving men an unfair deal. Here's how: T. Russel says that women now want to be taken care of. That's the kind of feminism that women want now. They want to be taken care of in a Patriarchy way, like in Joe Rogan's example of a man married to a woman, they had no kids, they got a divorce, and now this guy must pay his wife alimony for the rest of his life. That's insane in this day an d age. But where does this insane attitude come from?..... It comes from what I call "t he old deal"....Which means for most of our history, men had to protect and provide for women. In return women gave the man children and was the center of his family. Men dominated outside the home, in the world of work and politics and economic competition. Women had their sphere, and men had theirs. This was kind of a deal worked out, by the sexes. Each side gave of something: men had more responsibility financially for the woman, to make up for the fact that women were not his economic competitors outside the home, and they had to use all their energy for raising children. Men had the protector role, and so close to 100% of all combat deaths in history, were to men. And pretty much all hard and dangerous jobs in history have been done by men. In return women were all about home and hearth, and children.... And that was a fair deal between the sexes, that lasted a long time. Then science progressed and the modern world was invented. In the 1800s infant mortality was still at 50%, and people lived short lives, and there were no jobs for women outside the home, so they worked at home. Then when science conquered a lot of diseases, people lived longer, fewer babies died, and places appeared in the world...factories and offices...where women could work outside the home, and compete economically with men, in large numbers. Birth control was invented and feminism came along, and this picture meant that women could work outside the home. "The old deal" was broken....women recently became the direct economic competitors to women, for the first time in history. Women now became men's economic competitor's, and competitors for power of all sorts, in the world. Hillary is the latest example. Fina lly a woman had a serious shot at becoming President. Very soon we will have our first woman President. And women under 35 now earn more money than men, in America, and the women under 35 in America earn more money than men under 35. So women will dominate the workplace, and eventually be the man's equal at work. At least half the time, a woman will be your superior at work. And that raises a tricky issue: As I said at the beginning, and as T. Russel says, women still want to be treated as delicate kittens, and protected, even though they are now a man's competitor for social and economic and political power. And that sets up a real conundrum for men: Is this a good new deal for men? My answer: No, it's a horrible new deal for men. Here's why: Women now expect us men to protect them and kiss their rear ends, lik e in the old days, when they could get pregnant at any time, were vulnerable, and were focusing on having children. But today fewer children are being born, and women are at work, often being your superior at work....and competing with males at work, for money. And if you are not sufficiently compliant at work with women, you are labelled "sexist". Will men settle for this: for women bossing them around at work, and being often socially superior to them, at the same time as all men must, roughly speaking, kiss their rear ends, and cater to them, and protect them? Because that is the "new deal" for men. And it seems like this new deal between the genders won't work, to me. It seems like that is setting up a deal where women have much more power than men. Women now have the best of both worlds. They have the be st of the old deal: protection and care, by men. And at the same time, they have the b est of the old deal, from a male perspective: like men in times past, they get to be socially dominant and compete outside the home......the best of both worlds. There is something in that new gender balance package that doesn't feel right to me. It doesn't feel right, that men who marry a woman and have no children, should have to cater to a woman, and pay her money, till the day he dies. That seems a part of the old deal, when women really WERE vulnerable and needed protection. It seems like men are being taken for a ride, by women and by modern feminism. This new deal is not at all fair to men, in my opinion. This new power relationship between the sexes will never last. I can tell that because of all the comments below.....!...It is far too unfair to men, to last. Eventually men will rebel and demand change. Joe Rogan has figured this out, because his friend is the one paying money to his ex-wife, for the rest of his life. Joe said that was insane, in this day and age. I agree: Insane. Completely insane. This is a super interesting conversation, but neither of them has a firm enough understanding of family law. Thankfully I am a lawyer who specialised in family law. In Australia, alimony (aka spousal maintenance) is given when one spouse has sacrificed an income to support the other spouse. For example, if I didn't stop working to help my disabled son, my husband would have had to. Therefore, he would not have been able to work full time and receive promotions. A % of his current income is thanks to me. In oz, we don't have lifetime alimony. It is generally only given for a few years and must be proportionate to the years together. Example - 10 years together would receive about 4 years of alimony. Maybe America just has a really fucked up family law system.

Upon reaching Philadelphia, Blackwell boarded with Dr. William Elder and studied anatomy privately with Dr. Jonathan M. Out of desperation, she applied to twelve "country schools".[2] Medical education in the United States[edit] Portrait of Elizabeth Blackwell by Joseph Stanley Kozlowski, 1905. Syracuse University Medical School collection. In October, 1847, Blackwell was accepted as a medical student by Hobart College, then called Geneva Medical College, located in upstate New York. It is the theory of the political, economic, and social equality of the sexes. I started questioning gender based assumptions a long time ago- when I was 8. I was confused about being called disrespectful when I politely questioned what I was being taught in school, but everyone else seemed to beilve things with litte or no investigation. When at 14 I started to be de-sexualized by certain elements of the media. When at 15 Men started dropping out of colleges because they didn't want to appear masculine. When at 18 my female friends/and family demonized me every-time I expressed my feelings. I decided that I was a Meninist and this seemed uncomplicated to me. But my recent research has shown me that Meninism has become an unpopular word. Men are choosing not to identify as Meninist. Apparently I am among the ranks of Men who's expressions are seen as to strong, to aggressive, isolating, and anti-female- yet strangely attractive. Why has the word become such an uncomfortable one. I am from Britan! And I think it is right, that i am paid what I earned. I think it is right, that I should be able to make decisions about my own body. (applase) I think it is right the Men be involved on my behalf in the policy and decisions that will effect my life. I think it is right, that socially I am afforded the same respect as whamen. These rights I consider to be human rights; But I am one of the luck ones. My life is a sheer privilege. Because my parents didn't love me less because I was born an son.
